VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period in response to a special investigation (2024C0001132SI), and
compliance with this CAP is as follows: The first action step involved staff being
reminded of the different aspects of bed checks during sleeping hours each staff
meeting. The facility provided documentation of the agenda for each staff meeting
that took place weekly during this 6-month review period for the CAP. The second
action step involved staff being retrained on the procedure for bed room checks
and the facilty provided documentation that all staff were trained on this procedure
with an outline of the training and a staff attendence sign in sheet. The third action
step involved the Chief Administrator completing a video review once a week and
documenting the finding on a spreadsheet. The facility provided a copy of this
spreadsheet and there was documentation that a review was indeed completed as
outlined in the CAP. The fourth action step involved each staff signing an
acknowledtgement of the 15-minute room check procedure which the facility
documented occurred on 4/22/24. The fifth and final action step invovled all staff
being retrained on the facility confidentiality policy. The facility provided
documentation of this training occurring on several dates and copies of the staff
sign in sheet was provided. Overall, evidence provided supports the facility was
successful in following their action steps to ensure compliance with the CAP.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator evaluated the CAP for the special investigation
2024C0001132SI. It is documented that the specific aspects of the CAP that had a
positive impact on the facility involve an increase in the accuracy of documentation
of bed checks and compliance of random, variable check for each youth. Trainings
for staff are helping to support staff and allowing the facility to explore new and
innovative ways during the overnight hours. The overnight staff have been given a

document to help find different options of making the bed checks. They are
documented as also using an alarm for all bed checks to ensure they are making
the bed checks. The administration is continuing to follow up regarding any
possible barriers to the night shift completing their duty of bed checks. The Chief
Administrator is completing random camera observations weekly and documenting
the findings on a spreadsheet. Disciplinary action in the form of verbal and written
warning are being issued to staff if found not in compliance with the procedure of
the bed checks. The Chief Administrator also identified training to improve staff’s
understanding of the code of ethics in regard of the importance of documentation
being truthful and accurate. Overall, it is documented there is improvement in the
performance of staff. The Chief Administrator documents that there were no
unplanned discharges during this reporting period.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed reported changes in the policies and procedures for bed checks,
code of ethics, and confidentiality. Staff reported having training in these areas
and believe this has helped to provide a higher level of care for the youth. They
also believe administration is very supportive of their efforts to engage in best
practices.
One of three youth in the facility were verbal and understanding enough to be
interviewed. This youth reported feeling safe at the facility and believed he is
receiving appropriate services that are needed. He also reported receiving therapy
weekly both individual and group format. He is engaged in after school activities
which he enjoys. He reported staff are always with him and the other youth. The
other two youth were observed and their interactions with staff were appropriate.
Description of Agency Walk Through
This is an older two-story home (building) north of downtown Kalamazoo,
Michigan. The building is maintained and there is a regular maintenance schedule.
The building is approximately furnished as are the youth’s bedrooms. All
medication are appropriately locked and as are the cleaning supplies. There is a
good supply of food items including both fresh and frozen items for the youth. The
menu was posted as was the other required items. Bed check logs were reviewed
and found to be appropriate, and the facility has conducted the required
emergency drills each quarter. All plumbing is in working order and the fire
extinguishers are up to date.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes. It is recommended that the agency be issued a renewal of their regular
license.
